title: Who wants to be the seditious 50th?
text:
The Indian state has added 49 more people to its ‘anti-national’ list for writing a letter to the Prime Minister. More than the number, it is the profiles of these men and women booked for sedition that make the case, well, laughable. Among those on the ‘hit list’ are historian Ramachandra Guha and filmmakers Adoor Gopalakrishnan, Mani Ratnam, Shyam Benegal, Aparna Sen, and Anurag Kashyap.

That most of them work in the sphere of arts and culture should speak something about the character of whoever came up with the brilliant idea to get them booked. For the record, the FIR came after chief judicial magistrate Surya Kant Tiwari passed an order two months ago on a petition filed by a lawyer named Sudhir Kumar Ojha.

Here are some highlights from the letter which the magistrate found fit to be considered as chargeable for sedition, public nuisance, hurting religious feelings and insulting with an intent to provoke breach of peace.

The lynching of Muslims, dalits and other minorities must be stopped immediately.

Regrettably, ‘Jai Sri Ram’ has become a provocative war cry today that leads to law and order problems. It is shocking that so much violence should be perpetrated in the name of religion.

There is no democracy without dissent. People should not be branded ‘anti-national’ and ‘urban naxal’ or incarcerated because of dissent against the government.

Criticising the ruling party does not mean criticising the nation.

An open environment where dissent is not crushed only makes for a stronger nation.

If any of those points constitutes sedition or public nuisance, many of our great leaders including Mahatma Gandhi – if alive today – would’ve found it difficult to avoid litigation. In fact, many of them were jailed during their times because of dissent. If today’s powers that be choose to be no different from the British in employing tools of oppression, they should also expect an uprising similar to those against our erstwhile oppressors.

The self-appointed custodians of invented nationalism have so far found comfort in the silence of the tolerant. But that may not last long. If every citizen who believes in dissent and tolerance reproduces the ‘letter of 49’ and posts it to the Prime Minister, India Post will no longer be in the red.

But symbolism doesn’t work with the insensitive. Arab Spring didn’t happen in an instance, though the social media accelerated its reach. At the heart of every Occupy movement has been the respect and love for democracy and dissent. Strong-arm tactics and hit jobs on people who refuse to sing the chorus of distorted nationalism will push India to a movement of resistance and reclamation of rights.

And such a struggle will not be confined to social media, where trolls – by the paid and the paranoid – have been able to force people like Anurag Kashyap out of Twitter. Besides hashtags and handles, there will be people on the streets.

The case against the 49 who wrote to the Prime Minister may not stand judicial scrutiny, and none of them cares a damn about such paper tigers, but that our laws can be used as an instrument of threat against dissent is worrisome. What makes one sadder is that the by-product of such systemic attempt at building a monolithic nationalism is feeding and breeding intolerance. The mails I would get for this column will bear testimony to this.

To troll me, wait for the online version of this column on my Twitter handle @Arun_ Ram. Please send your threats and abuses to my email mentioned below. The best of them will be published on this page.
